awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Distributed Iterative Control of Soft Robotic Arms
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will create a new method of controlling compliant robot manipulators resembling octopus arms or elephant trunks, and will experimentally validate these new control laws. This project will explore two innovative aspects. First, control will be distributed. That is, a large number of sensors and actuators will be spread throughout the manipulator, and information gathered by each sensor will be used to control only a small number of nearby actuators. This distributed control strategy avoids the transmission of large amounts of data across the structure, and eliminates the need for a powerful central computer to process this flood of data. Second, the control law will be iterative. That is, the soft manipulator will learn to achieve its objectives over multiple attempts. Although the approach taken is not explicitly based on biological behavior, both these features are present in animals that manipulate objects using compliant appendages. Computer simulations will be used to study performance of the new control laws on extremely complex robots, with hundreds of individually controllable segments. Physical experiments will be conducted on systems with between five and ten such segments. The modeling and control approaches will advance the national health and economic prosperity, by enabling reliable autonomous operation of soft multi-segment robots, to increase their usability in numerous applications, including manufacturing, surgery, search and rescue, navigation, and personal home assistance.

This project will explore novel distributed planning and control approaches for multi-segment soft robotic systems. In contrast to the large amounts of training data required by machine learning, this approach aims to create intuitive and computationally efficient algorithms with high robustness and scalability. Specific research goals include i) novel 2-D and 3-D goal reaching and obstacle avoidance algorithms, using only local sensor measurements and information processing, ii) feasible high-fidelity dynamic models to capture non-linear material properties and pressure dynamics, iii) a robust iterative learning control algorithm for gravity compensation and motion control of the soft arm, and iv) validation of the control laws using a physical multi-segment soft robotic arm.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Inspired by dexterous manipulation capabilities of elephant trunks, the research team (''we'' thereafter) explore new design, modeling, and control approaches for compliant robot manipulators in this project. We focused on a class of pneumatic-driven soft continuum actuators, built computational and analytical models of these actuators, and developed control algorithms for precise position tracking and adaptive stiffness modulation in various tasks. The integration of design, modeling and control enables numerous applications of the soft manipulators, including manufacturing, agriculture, search and rescue, navigation, surgery, rehabilitation, and personal home assistance.

Three versions of soft robotic manipulators have been designed and fabricated in this project. We started with elastomeric Soft Poly Limb (eSPL) which consisted of multiple three-chamber ring-reinforced actuators in series. Each actuator can perform bending and elongation motions. The eSPL was able to manipulate objects using an end-effector, and more importantly, its own soft body to conform around and lift an object up to 2.35 times its own weight. The second design was based on woven non-stretch fabric bending arrays. The fabric Soft Poly Limb (fSPL) is collapsible to half of its original length, and can safely carry loads 10.1 times its body weight by wrapping around the object. The third design employs knit stretch fabric actuators. These actuators are fully collapsible when deflated and can generate bending, elongating, twisting, and a combination of these motion profiles upon inflation with different reinforcement patterns. An untethered knit fabric soft continuum robot module was also developed with embedded fabric sensing. For each type of the actuators, we characterized force and kinematic outputs with different geometry designs and material selections. These novel fabric soft pneumatic actuators (FSPA) are low-cost, lightweight, and customizable for high DOF motion profiles. They set the foundation for successful deployment of soft manipulators into real-world tasks.

Both computational and analytical models have been developed for the three types of actuators. Finite element method (FEM) models demonstrated accurate prediction of the force, torque, and kinematic outputs of the actuators. We also developed a toolkit based on the FEM models for design optimization by varying the geometry parameters without the need for frequent prototyping or experiments of soft actuators, which significantly accelerate future soft actuator designs. For analytical modeling, we developed a linear parameter-varying model for the elastomeric actuators and an augmented rigid-arm model based on piecewise constant curvature assumption for the woven fabric actuators. The dynamic models have been used to design feedback (e.g., PID, H-infinity, and sliding mode control) and feedforward (e.g., iterative learning control) controllers for precise tracking of end-effector position, with the kinematic reference for each segment determined using a decentralized iterative planning algorithm. Most recently, we have extended the controller design to consider stiffness modulation for intelligent interaction with the environment. Specifically, a disturbance observer was employed to estimate the interaction force and adjust the kinematic reference in real time.

This This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project has made an impact to the field of soft robotics by creating 1) a class of novel fabric soft pneumatic actuators (FSPAs), 2) computational models of FSPAs for design optimization, 3) dynamic models of FSPAs for precision position control, and 4) adaptive stiffness controllers for interaction with the environment.

This project has generated positive societal impacts with numerous potential applications to improve the efficiency of work (e.g., as a manipulator in manufacturing), quality of life (e.g., as a wearable assistive and augmentation device), and accessibility of robotic technologies (thanks to its low cost and inherent safety). This project also leads to multiple granted and pending patents for technology transfer and commercialization. This project has also created significant impacts in education: three PhD students, eight MS students, and seven undergraduate students (three in the REU program) actively participated in this project. One PhD student has graduated, and he plans to develop his career in academia after completing his post-doctoral training. The soft actuators and manipulators have been integrated into the robotics and control classes, and demonstrated in various outreach activities, conference workshops, and media outlets. All the publications resulted from this project have been made available in the NSF Public Access Repository.


Last Modified: 01/02/2022
Modified by: Wenlong Zhang
